p.text: An application for a garnishee order in respect of a judgment is to be made by way of notice of motion.
Unless the court orders otherwise, a notice of motion under this rule:
may be dealt with in the absence of the parties, and
need not be served on the judgment debtor or the proposed garnishee.
The application must indicate the extent (if any) to which the judgment debt has been satisfied under any writ of execution, garnishee order or charging order issued by the court.

A judgment debt may be enforced by a garnishee order made under ss 106(1)(b) and 117 of the Civil Procedure Act. Garnishee proceedings permit a judgment creditor to satisfy the debt from moneys due to the judgment debtor from third parties (garnishees). Execution itself does not extend to debts owed to the judgment debtor but garnishment is an analogous process which brings them into the same position as chattels for that purpose: White, Son & Pill v Stennings [1911] 2 KB 418; Tile Centre v Symonds; Ex parte Kyritis [1972] VR 295. Garnishee proceedings are judicial proceedings and cannot be restrained by injunction: Llewellyn v Carrickford [1970] 2 All ER 24.
The approved form is Form 69 : Notice of motion for garnishee order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.35] r 39.35 Affidavit in support of application for garnishee order

leg:heading.title: Affidavit in support of application for garnishee order

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, an applicant for a garnishee order must file an affidavit in support of the application, being an affidavit sworn not more than 14 days before the date of filing.
The affidavit in support:
must identify the garnishee, and any debts that appear to be owed by the garnishee to the judgment debtor, and
must state the amount payable under the judgment, together with any costs and interest payable in relation to the judgment, as at the date of swearing of the affidavit, and

if the judgment was entered as a result of the filing of a cost assessor’s certificate, must include a statement to that effect, together with a statement to the effect that the determination set out in the certificate:
is not subject to any suspension under section 377(1) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 that has not been ended under section 377(2) of that Act, and
is not subject to any suspension under section 386(1) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 that has not been ended under section 386(2) of that Act.
[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[23], effective 8 December 2006]

Any application by the judgment creditor for a garnishee order in relation to a judgment debt that has been the subject of an instalment order that has ceased to have effect may not be granted unless the judgment creditor has filed an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s failure to comply with the order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.36] r 39.36 Form of garnishee order for debts (cf SCR Part 46, rule 3; Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

leg:heading.title: Form of garnishee order for debts (cf SCR Part 46, rule 3; Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

p.text: A garnishee order for debts must direct the garnishee to pay to the judgment creditor, to the extent of the amount outstanding under the judgment, all money:
held by the garnishee for or on behalf of the judgment debtor, or
owed by the garnishee to the judgment debtor.
The amount outstanding under the judgment must be specified in the order.

The approved form for a garnishee order for debts is Form 70 . Form 71 is the approved form for a Garnishee order for wages and salary. A garnishment notice operates to attach, to the extent of the amount specified in the notice, all debts due or accruing from the garnishee to the judgment debtor, regardless of whether they are specified in the notice: s 117 CPA cf old SCR Pt 46 r 5. Upon service of a garnishment notice, all debts due or accruing from the garnishee to the judgment debtor are attached, whether or not they are described in the notice. Identification or description of a particular debt is not essential to the validity of the garnishment notice: ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 at [5]–[7] per Brereton J (notice under the old SCR — the garnishment notice did not refer to nor provide any particulars of any debt said to be due but instead referred to an arbitral award) citing De Pass v Capital Industries Corporation Ltd [1891] 1 QB 216 at 218 .

Upon service of a garnishment notice, all debts due or accruing from the garnishee to the judgment debtor are attached, whether or not they are described in the notice, and identification or description of a particular debt is not essential to the validity of the garnishment notice: ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.37] r 39.37 Form of garnishee order for wage or salary (cf SCR Part 46, rule 3; Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

leg:heading.title: Form of garnishee order for wage or salary (cf SCR Part 46, rule 3; Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

p.text: A garnishee order for wage or salary must direct the garnishee to pay to the judgment creditor:
during the period for which the order is in force, and
to the extent of the amount outstanding under the judgment,
such amounts, from the wages or salary payable by the garnishee to the judgment debtor, as are specified in the order.
The amount outstanding under the judgment must be specified in the order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.38] r 39.38 Court may refuse to make garnishee order (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

leg:heading.title: Court may refuse to make garnishee order (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97; Act No 11 1970, section 47)

p.text: The court may refuse to make a garnishee order if of the opinion that such an order is inappropriate.
Without limiting subrule (1), the reasons that may lead the court into forming such an opinion may include:
the smallness of the amount recoverable under the judgment debt, and
the smallness of the debt, wage or salary to be attached.
Legislation cited in [39.38.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 [s 124.5].
See [s 124.5] of the CPA.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.39] r 39.39 When garnishee order takes effect

p.text: A garnishee order takes effect when it is served on the garnishee.

Unless the notice is limited to a specified amount all debts mentioned in the garnishment notice are attached. The garnishee is then prevented from dealing with any part of the debt for any other purpose — even though the liability to the judgment debtor exceeds the latter’s liability to the garnishor. Thus a bank may dishonour cheques drawn by the judgment debtor: Rogers v Whiteley [1892] AC 118 . However, service of the notice does not operate as an assignment of the debt but merely creates a charge over it: Galbraith v Grimshaw & Baxter [1910] 1 KB 339 ; Re Combined Weighing and Advertising Machine Co (1889) 43 Ch D 99 ; Chatterton v Watney (1881) 17 Ch D 259 . Consequently, neither a bankruptcy notice Ex parte Chinery (1884) 12 QBD 342 nor a winding up petition can be served in respect of a garnishee because the latter does not give rise to the relationship of debtor and creditor: Re Steel Wing Co Ltd [1921] 1 Ch 349; [1920] All ER 292 ; but see Pritchett v English & Colonial Syndicate [1899] 2 QB 428 ; Re Combined Weighing and Advertising Machine Co, above. If another person obtains a charge before the order has been served the debt will not be bound: WJ Adams & Co Ltd v Blencowe (1929) 46 WN (NSW) 150 ; Re General Horticultural Co (1886) 32 Ch D 512 at 515 ; Re London Consolidated Pressed Hinge Co Ltd [1905] 1 Ch 576 ; Holt v Heatherfield Trust Ltd [1942] 2 KB 1 ; MG Charley Pty Ltd v FH Wells Pty Ltd [1963] NSWR 22; (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 754 . The judgment debtor may assign any surplus which will remain after satisfying the garnishee order. After such an assignment the garnishee cannot apply any surplus to satisfy any garnishee order served after receiving notice of the assignment: Yates v Terry [1902] 1 KB 527 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.40] r 39.40 Affidavit that no debt due or accruing (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97A; Act No 11 1970, section 47A)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit that no debt due or accruing (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97A; Act No 11 1970, section 47A)

p.text: A garnishee who believes that:
no debt from the garnishee to the judgment debtor was due or accruing when the garnishee order was served on the garnishee, or
no wage or salary will become payable by the garnishee to the judgment debtor during the period for which the order will be in force,
may serve on the judgment creditor a statement to that effect, verified by affidavit, being a statement that contains a summary of the grounds on which the garnishee’s belief is based.
A disclosure of any information in an affidavit under subrule (1) does not, if the disclosure was reasonable in the circumstances, subject the garnishee to any action, liability, claim or demand.
The approved form for a garnishee’s statement that no debt was due or accruing or no wage or salary will be payable is Form 72.

The garnishee can dispute their debt liability to the judgment debtor, but not the. validity of the garnishor’s judgment against the judgment debtor: Watson v Morrow (1880) 6 VLR (L) 134 ; Granger v Granger [1919] VLR 288 . Neither can a garnishee set off a debt owed to them by the garnishor: Sampson v Seaton Ry (1875) LR 10 QB 28. However, a garnishee can both set-off against the judgment debtor: Nathan v Giles (1814) 5 Taunt 958; Tapp v Jones (1875) LR 10 QB 593; and can also rely upon a cross-claim against the judgment debtor: Hale v Victoria Plumbing Co [1966] 2 QB 746 .

The making of a garnishee order absolute is discretionary. The court might decline to make an order absolute even if indebtedness is established: see ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 at [69]–[77] per Brereton J (indebtedness not established — but even if established application for payment declined on basis garnishor had knowledge of foreign corporate reorganisation proceedings in which it was participating and seeking to prove its debt); Pritchard v Westminster Bank Ltd [1969] 1 All ER 999; [1969] 1 WLR 547 (garnishee order set aside on basis that it would prefer the plaintiff over all other creditors). However, where a debt is attached to satisfy a local judgment before a foreign bankruptcy intervenes, the attachment is valid and prevails over the foreign bankruptcy: Galbraith v Grimshaw [1910] AC 508 at 510 (Scottish debt — garnishee order served on English firm which owed debt to judgment debtor before judgment debtor’s estate was sequestrated). The rationale being that while local courts recognise foreign bankruptcies (and similar administrations), they do not recognise foreign rules of relation-back: ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 at [63]–[68] per Brereton J.

Ordinarily, a garnishee is not allowed costs. However, that rule does not apply where the garnishee appears and shows that no debt is due by it: ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 at [69]–[77] per Brereton J (garnishment notice discharged and judgment creditor ordered to pay garnishee’s costs) citing Willis v Municipality of Five Dock (1895) 11 WN (NSW) 112 ; Dean v Dwyer (1924) 41 WN (NSW) 67.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.41] r 39.41 Lien or claim of third person (cf Act No 9 1973, section 104)

leg:heading.title: Lien or claim of third person (cf Act No 9 1973, section 104)

p.text: This rule applies in circumstances in which the garnishee claims that some person, other than the judgment debtor, is or may be entitled to:
any money paid under a garnishee order, or
any debt, wage or salary attached by a garnishee order, or
any charge or lien on, or other interest in, any such money, debt, wage or salary.

In these circumstances, the court may hear and determine the garnishee’s claim and give such judgment or make such order in respect of the claim (including an order barring the claim and an order for the payment into court by a judgment creditor of money received under the garnishee order) as the nature of the case requires.

It is the garnishee’s duty to acquaint the court with any competing claim or lien of which they are aware: The Leader (1868) LR 2 A & E 314; Plunkett v Barclays Bank Ltd [1936] 2 KB 107; [1936] 1 All ER 653 ; Richards v Jager [1909] VLR 140 . If a third party has a valid lien or charge over the debt, the prioroity of that claim must be given effect: MG Charley Pty Ltd v FH Wells Pty Ltd [1963] NSWR 22; (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 754 . But if the third party claim is merely by way of a floating charge which has not crystallised there is no priority that will defeat the making of a garnishee order: Evans v Rival Granite Quarries Ltd [1910] 2 KB 979 . (The third party claimant may have a right to appear: and assert their claim: Brunet v Miller (1897) 22 VLR 496 ; cf Bank of New South Wales v Coleman (1898) 14 WN (NSW) 155 ; MG Charley Pty Ltd v FH Wells Pty Ltd , above.) No garnishee order for payment will be made if the judgment debtor’s entitlement against the garnishee relates to property in which third parties have a beneficial interest (eg, as trust beneficiaries): Roberts v Death (1881) 8 QBD 319 ; Plunkett v Barclays Bank Ltd , above; Bank of New South Wales v Coleman (1898) 14 WN (NSW) 155 .

For the purposes of section 123(2)(a) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, the prescribed amount that may be retained by the garnishee out of money deducted under a garnishee order is as specified in item 4 of Schedule 3.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.43] r 39.43 Notice required for certain attached debts yet to accrue (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97C; Act No 11 1970, section 47C)

leg:heading.title: Notice required for certain attached debts yet to accrue (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97C; Act No 11 1970, section 47C)

p.text: If a garnishee order attaches a debt that is due for payment to the judgment debtor more than 28 days after service of the order on the garnishee, the garnishee must, within that period of 28 days, cause notice of that fact to be served on the judgment creditor.
The notice must specify:
the date on which the debt is, or is likely to be, due for payment to the judgment debtor, and
if the amount of the debt is less than the unpaid amount of the judgment debt specified in the garnishee order, the amount of the debt.
The giving of false or misleading information in such a notice constitutes an offence under section 307B of the Crimes Act 1900.
